title: Now even George Osborne's own father-in-law slams the Hinkley C...
text:
Now even George Osborne's own father-in-law slams the Hinkley C nuclear deal By TristanCork | Posted: October 23, 2015 Suzanne Plunkett/PA Chancellor George Osborne and China's Yu Guangzhou sign an agreement as Prime Minister David Cameron and China's President Xi Jinping watch Now even George Osborne's own father-in-law slams the Hinkley C nuclear deal X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Pictures: Suzanne Plunkett/PA Chancellor George Osborne and China's Yu Guangzhou sign an agreement as Prime Minister David Cameron and China's... Comments (0) 
Chancellor George Osborne's own father-in-law has slammed the deal he signed with the Chinese to fund the building of a new nuclear power station at Hinkley Point in Somerset, saying we would all be paying 'eye-watering' energy prices because it is such a bad deal. 
Lord Howell of Guildford, himself a former Conservative energy minister, said he suspected the deal would not be repeated because of the high price the Government paid – which will be passed onto the nation through higher energy bills. 
Mr Osborne and the Tory Government gave 'risk-free guarantees' to two Chinese state-owned energy companies to invest 33.5 per cent of the cost of Hinkley C, with the French state-owned energy firm EDF funding the rest of the cost and building the plant. 
The deal signed this week to build Hinkley C has long been criticised by environmental campaigners, more recently by former defence chiefs and security analysts worried about the threat to national security of involving China in building and running nuclear power stations in Britain, and now the finances of the deal itself have been criticised from experts within Mr Osborne's own family. Related content 'A heartbeat from absolute catastrophe' - how our worst train crash ever didn't happen in Wiltshire 
"It should be no surprise that it needs a French state company, a Chinese state-owned company and the British Government, plus eye-watering price penalties on all industries and households for years to come, to keep a project of this size and design going forward and, of course, endless Government guarantees for risk-free returns to the investors," said Lord Howell, the father of Mr Osborne's wife Frances, who is the Tories' deputy leader in the House of Lords. 
"I suspect that it will be the last of its kind in the line," he added. 
To secure EDF even contemplating building a third nuclear power station at Hinkley Point, Mr Osborne guaranteed the French firm a 'strike price' of £92.50 for every megawatt of power produced per hour, which is almost double the basic price of energy in the market at the moment. 
It will mean the cost of energy for consumers will rise when Hinkley C comes on line, which could be within ten years if work to build it goes smoothly. 
The £24 billion power plant is expected to be the most expensive ever built, and critics have said the Government should either have funded it themselves, or put the investment into increasingly cheaper renewable energy sources. 
EDF have defended the deal, pointing out that the 'strike price' for many other forms of energy, including hydro, wind turbines and solar farms, is much higher. 
The director general of the World Nuclear Association, Agneta Rising, said more countries needed to follow Britain's lead and build more nuclear power stations to bring the costs down. 
"New nuclear construction around the world is at the highest level for 25 years, but we need to see more countries learning from the UK's example to support nuclear energy among a mix of generation technologies that are fit for the future," she said. 
But Greenpeace's UK chief scientist, Dr Doug Parr, said the decision to build Hinkley C would be questioned by British people who aren't even born yet. 
"Our grandchildren will one day wonder why their bills are propping up a foreign-owned, outdated, and costly nuclear industry instead of supporting cutting-edge UK firms producing cheap clean energy," he said. 
"There's no other reason for the government to go through with this rotten deal but saving George Osborne's face," he added.
